elements.content: Solvothermal treatments of Zn(II) salts and 3-amino-1H-1,2,4-triazole in mixed water−dimethylformamide solvent produced a two-dimensional, wavy layer structure [Zn(atz)(fa)] (1, Hfa = formic acid) with a 4.82 Zn(atz) topology. While carbonate, oxalate, and aliphatic dicarboxylates are used to replace the terminal formate ligand, a series of three-dimensional pillared-layer metal−organic frameworks, namely, [Zn2(atz)2(CO3)]·3H2O (2), [Zn4(atz)4(CO3)(ox)]·3H2O (3, H2ox = oxalic acid), [Zn2(atz)2(sca)] (4, H2sca = succinic acid), [Zn2(atz)2(ada)] (5, H2ada = adipic acid), [Zn2(atz)2(sba)] (6, H2sba = suberic acid), [Zn2(atz)2(aza)] (7, H2aza = azelaic acid), and [Zn2(atz)2(sea)] (8, H2sea = sebacylic acid), are constructed. The crystal structural analyses demonstrate that the dicarboxylates have a significant impact on the Zn(atz) layers, which adopt various corrugated configurations in these three-dimensional metal−organic frameworks due to the different lengths and geometries of these pillars. Thermal stabilities of these compounds were examined by thermogravimetric analysis, while N2 adsorption measurements were analyzed for the porous 2 and 3.

elements.content: Synthesis and characterization of porous metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) are of great current interest because of their intriguing structures and potential applications on gas adsorption/separation, ion exchange, catalysis, and so on. One strategy for the construction of porous MOFs is based primarily on the proper selection of inorganic building blocks as nodes, such as Zn4O or paddle wheels, which are called secondary building units (SBUs), and rigid organic bridging ligands as linkers, such as dicarboxylates or 4,4′-bipyridine. Another rational strategy is the pillared-layer method, in which the layers are vertically shored up with molecular pillars. The advantage of this strategy is that one-dimensional (1D), two-dimensional (2D), or even three-dimensional (3D) open channels may be controlled and adjusted by use of different pillars, since the length of pillar and the pore size are closely related. In general, changing the pillar does not affect the structure of the layer. Useful chemical and physical properties such as hydrophilic/hydrophobic character, hydrogen bonding, and open metal site can be easily obtained by the introduction of functional pillars. Moreover, the use of flexible pillars may lead to dynamic porous MOFs that can shrink and expand. Nevertheless, very flexible long-chain fatty dicarboxylates have been rarely used as pillars in assembling 3D pillared-layer structures.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Synthesis and characterization of porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are of great current interest because of their intriguing structures and potential applications on gas adsorption/separation, ion exchange, catalysis, and so on. One strategy for the construction of porous MOFs is based primarily on the proper selection of inorganic building blocks as nodes, such as Zn4O or paddle wheels, which are called secondary building units (SBUs), and rigid organic bridging ligands as linkers, such as dicarboxylates or 4,4'-bipyridine. Another rational strategy is the pillared-layer method, in which the layers are vertically shored up with molecular pillars. The advantage of this strategy is that one-dimensional (1D), two-dimensional (2D), or even three-dimensional (3D) open channels may be controlled and adjusted by use of different pillars, since the length of pillar and the pore size are closely related. In general, changing the pillar does not affect the structure of the layer. Useful chemical and physical properties such as hydrophilic/hydrophobic character, hydrogen bonding, and open metal site can be easily obtained by the introduction of functional pillars. Moreover, the use of flexible pillars may lead to dynamic porous MOFs that can shrink and expand. Nevertheless, very flexible long-chain fatty dicarboxylates have been rarely used as pillars in assembling 3D pillared-layer structures.

elements.content: During our systematic investigation on metal−triazolate frameworks, we found that binary 1,2,4-triazolate compounds have certain flexible characteristics, such as the formation of a number of supramolecular isomers and dynamic structural transformations. Therefore, we anticipated that novel flexible pillared-layer structures may be constructed by metal 1,2,4-triazolate (tz) layer and aliphatic dicarboxylate pillars. For this purpose, 3-amino-1H-1,2,4-triazole (Hatz), as a not widely used ligand in the field of coordination polymers, is chosen. Solvothermal treatment of Zn(II) salt and Hatz in water and dimethylformamide (DMF) produced a 2D, wavy layer structure [Zn(atz)(fa)] (1, Hfa = formic acid) with a 4.82 Zn(atz) topology. In a conventional strategy, the terminal carboxylate fa can be replaced by rigid dicarboxylates to construct 3D pillared-layer structures. On the other hand, we introduced a number of unique molecular pillars, such as carbonate, oxalate, and aliphatic dicarboxylates, into the reaction system. A series of 3D pillared-layer MOFs, namely, [Zn2(atz)2(CO3)]·3H2O (2), [Zn4(atz)4(CO3)(ox)]·3H2O (3, H2ox = oxalic acid), [Zn2(atz)2(sca)] (4, H2sca = succinic acid), [Zn2(atz)2(ada)] (5, H2ada = adipic acid), [Zn2(atz)2(sba)] (6, H2sba = suberic acid), [Zn2(atz)2(aza)] (7, H2aza = azelaic acid), and [Zn2(atz)2(sea)] (8, H2sea = sebacylic acid), are successfully synthesized. Herein, we report the syntheses, crystal structures, and sorption properties of these new pillared-layer MOFs.

elements.content: Commercially available reagents were used as received without further purification. Infrared spectra were obtained from KBr pellets on a Bruker TENSOR 27 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer in the 400−4000 cm−1 region. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. Thermal gravimetry (TG) was carried out with a NETZSCH TG 209 system at a rate of 10 °C/min in a nitrogen atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded with Cu Kα radiation (1.5418 Å) on a RIGAKU D/max 2200 VPC X-ray diffractometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

Commercially available reagents were used as received without further purification. Infrared spectra were obtained from KBr pellets on a Bruker TENSOR 27 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer in the 400-4000 cm-1 region. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. Thermal gravimetry (TG) was carried out with a NETZSCH TG 209 system at a rate of 10 °C/min in a nitrogen atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded with Cu Kα radiation (1.5418 Å) on a RIGAKU D/max 2200 VPC X-ray diffractometer.

elements.content: The sorption isotherms for N2 gas were measured with an automatic volumetric adsorption apparatus (Micrometrics ASAP 2010) at 77 K. The as-synthesized samples were placed in a quartz tube and dried under high vacuum at 373 K for 10 h to remove the solvated molecules prior to measurements. The BET surface area was calculated from a line regression plot of 1/[W(P 0/P − 1)] vs P/P 0 (where W is the total volume absorbed at a particular P/P 0 point and P 0 is 1 atm pressure) within the range 0.02 > P/P 0 > 0.250.
elements.clean_text:
Sorption Measurements

The sorption isotherms for N2 gas were measured with an automatic volumetric adsorption apparatus (Micrometrics ASAP 2010) at 77 K. The as-synthesized samples were placed in a quartz tube and dried under high vacuum at 373 K for 10 h to remove the solvated molecules prior to measurements. The BET surface area was calculated from a line regression plot of 1/[W(P 0/P - 1)] vs P/P 0 (where W is the total volume absorbed at a particular P/P 0 point and P 0 is 1 atm pressure) within the range 0.02 > P/P 0 > 0.250.

elements.content: Diffraction intensities were collected on a Bruker Apex CCD area-detector diffractometer (Mo Kα, λ = 0.71073 Å) at T = 293(2) K. Absorption corrections were applied by using multiscan program SADABS. The structures were solved with direct methods and refined with a full-matrix least-squares technique on F 2 with the SHELXTL program package. Anisotropic thermal parameters were applied to all nonhydrogen atoms except for the serious disordered atoms. The organic hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically (C−H 0.96 Å) and refined with isotropic temperature factors. Crystallographic data were summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles were summarized in Table S1 of the .

Solvothermal reaction is employed to synthesize all of the compounds in mixed water−DMF solvent. In 1, the formate should result from the hydrolysis of DMF. During our investigation, this compound was reported, although the formate was suggested to result from decarboxylation of 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole-5-carboxylic acid. In addition to the oxalate pillar, carbonate also exists in 3, which may be generated by partial decomposition of oxalic acid under hydrothermal condition. Similar pillar-layer structures were also successfully constructed by C4, C6, C8, C9, and C10 aliphatic dicarboxylates. However, such a pillared-layer structure could not be obtained by using malonic acid under various hydrothermal conditions, which should be ascribed to the preference of malonate for a bidentate chelating mode over a ditopic bridging mode. In the case of glutaric acid, the pillared-layer structure could not be obtained either; instead, a complicated 3D structure is formed. These observations indicate that only certain bridging pillars with suitable sizes and/or geometries can be used to connect this 4.82 Zn(atz) layer.

Results and Discussion

Synthesis

Solvothermal reaction is employed to synthesize all of the compounds in mixed water-DMF solvent. In 1, the formate should result from the hydrolysis of DMF. During our investigation, this compound was reported, although the formate was suggested to result from decarboxylation of 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole-5-carboxylic acid. In addition to the oxalate pillar, carbonate also exists in 3, which may be generated by partial decomposition of oxalic acid under hydrothermal condition. Similar pillar-layer structures were also successfully constructed by C4, C6, C8, C9, and C10 aliphatic dicarboxylates. However, such a pillared-layer structure could not be obtained by using malonic acid under various hydrothermal conditions, which should be ascribed to the preference of malonate for a bidentate chelating mode over a ditopic bridging mode. In the case of glutaric acid, the pillared-layer structure could not be obtained either; instead, a complicated 3D structure is formed. These observations indicate that only certain bridging pillars with suitable sizes and/or geometries can be used to connect this 4.82 Zn(atz) layer.

elements.content: The crystal structure of 1 is depicted in Figure . One tetrahedral zinc(II) ion, one tridentate atz ligand, and one formate are found in an asymmetric unit. Similar to the copper(I) and silver(I) triazolates, the μ3-atz ligands and zinc(II) ions build up wavy 2D Zn(atz) layers. The coordination sphere of Zn(II) is completed by a monodentate formate ligand. The uncoordinated formate oxygen donor forms a hydrogen bond [O···H−N 2.926(5) Å] with the atz amino group, furnishing a pseudobidentate mode of the carboxylate. This hydrogen bond has significant impact on the orientation of the carboxylate ligand, which may be favorable for replacement of a dicarboxylate ligand as a pillar to connect these layers. From the topological point of view, the Zn(atz) layer in 1 has the same 2D 4.82 topology as that of the known copper(I) and silver(I) triazolates (Figure ). However, the Zn(atz) layer in 1 is not planar but corrugated because Zn(II) is tetrahedrally coordinated. To quantitatively describe the structural features of these compounds, several structural parameters for the Zn(atz) layer and the upcoming pillared-layer structures are introduced (Scheme ): Angle ω refers to the torsion angle between the adjacent four-membered rings, angle ϕ represents the distortion of the layer, d 1 is the amplitude of the layer, d 2 is the interlayer spacing, and φ is the slanting angle between the layer and the pillar. For example, in this original 2D layer, ω is 68.0°, ϕ is 115.1°, and d 1 is 2.56 Å (Table ). For a planar structure such as the copper(I) triazolate, these parameters are very close to 0°, 180°, and 0 Å, respectively.

The asymmetric unit of 2 contains one atz ligand, one tetrahedrally coordinated zinc(II) ion, half of a carbonate ion (located on a mirror plane), and one and a half water molecules. The 4.82 Zn(atz) layers [Zn−N 1.982(3)−2.020(4) Å and N−Zn−N 97.45(1)−120.45(1)°] of 2 are connected by the carbonate pillars via coordination bonds [Zn−O 1.917(3) Å and O−Zn−N 99.8(2)−123.3(2)°] into a 3D pillared-layer structure (Figure ). As compared to 1, the layer in 2 (ω = 78.6°, ϕ = 98.8°, and d 1 = 2.67 Å) is slightly distorted upon formation of the 3D pillared-layer structure by the carbonate pillars. Carbonate ions support the layer vertically (φ 90°), generating 1D channels along the a-axis. Taking the van der Waals radii into account, the dimensions of these channels are ca. 3.24 × 4.21 Å2. The solvent accessible volume constitutes ca. 36.3% of 2. The interlayer distance d 2 (8.10 Å) is larger than that of 1 (6.25 Å). In a view of topology, the connectivity of the tetrahedrally coordinated Zn(II) and tridentate atz ligand can be simplified to be 4-connected and 3-connected nodes, respectively, giving rise to a (3,4)-connected net with a Schläfli symbol (4.6.8)(4.62.83).

elements.content: There are one tetrahedrally coordinated and one octahedrally coordinated Zn(II) ions, two atz ligands, half of a carbonate ion (located on a glide plane), half of a oxalate ion (located on an inversion center), as well as one and a half water molecules in an asymmetric unit of 3. The tetrahedral zinc(II) ion is similar to that in 2 [Zn−N 1.980(4)−2.004(4) Å, Zn−O 1.993(4) Å, N−Zn−N 105.1(2)−109.81(2)°, and O−Zn−N 99.8(2)−123.3(2)°], whereas the octahedral one is coordinated by three N from three atz ligands [Zn−N 2.058(4)−2.091(4) Å], two oxygen atoms from a chelating oxalate [Zn−O 2.119(4)−2.138(4) Å], as well as one aqua molecule [Zn−O 2.42(1) Å]. With a similar pillaring fashion of 2, 1D channels are also found along the c-axis in 3 (Figure ). Although the potential solvent accessible volume constitutes ca. 27.9% of 3, the channels of the oxalate layer are too small for diffusion of guest molecules (2.12 × 2.31 Å2). In 3, the Zn(atz) layer configuration is slightly changed from that of 2, as the layers are alternatively pillared by carbonate and oxalate groups. Moreover, the (3,4)-connected topology of 3 also changes to (4.6.8)(4.62.83)(4.82)(4.85).

elements.content: Although 4 and 5 crystallize in two different space groups, their asymmetric units are very similar: one tetrahedral zinc(II), one deprotonated atz ligand, and half of a dicarboxylate [Zn−N 1.99(1)−2.04(1) Å and Zn−O 1.95(1) Å for 4 and Zn−N 1.987(5)−2.039(5) Å and Zn−O 1.968(9) Å for 5], while sca locates on an inversion center and ada on a glide plane. The 4.82 Zn(atz) layers are supported by the sca or ada pillars in a different way as compared with 2 and 3. The pillars are no more perpendicular to the layer (φ = 65.3° and 68.1° for 4 and 5, respectively), and no channel can be observed parallel to the layers (Figures ). Although it seems some channels appear along the c-axis in 4, which are actually filled with the amino groups of atz and uncoordinated oxygen atoms of sca. The ϕ angles of 4 and 5 are smaller than those of 2 and 3, indicating the layer is more distorted. Interestingly, the amino groups in 5 surrounding the 8-membered ring of the 4.82 net protrude vertically outward the layer, giving rise to very small channel (size 2.65 × 2.65 Å2) perpendicular to the layer. Both 4 and 5 have the same connecting pattern and have the same topology (4.82)(4.82.103).

elements.content: Compounds 6−8 all crystallize in the same space group of Iba2. Both 7 and 8 have similar asymmetric units, that is, two Zn(II) ions, two atz ligands, and one aliphatic dicarboxylate. Zn(II) ions in 7 and 8 are all tetrahedrally coordinated by three N from atz [Zn−N 1.99(1)−2.04(1) Å] and one O from dicarboxylate [Zn−O 1.95(2)−2.00(2) Å]. However, 6 possesses a very long b-axis of ca. 75 Å, corresponding to the asymmetric unit content of six Zn(II) ions, six atz ligands, and three sba. Five zinc(II) atoms are four-coordinated (three N atoms from atz ligans and one oxygen atom from sba), and one znic(II) is five coordinated by three N atoms of atz and two oxygen atoms from a chelating end of sba. The Zn(atz) layers of 6−8 are remarkably corrugated, as shown by their d 1 values 6.77, 6.49, and 5.52 Å, respectively, which are significantly larger than that of 1 (2.56 Å). The long aliphatic dicarboxylates twist and fill up the space between the layers, showing their unique flexibilities. Consequently, no porous structure is observed in these three compounds (Figures ). No matter how the layers are distorted and the pillars are slanted or twisted, the 3D structures of 6−8 can all be assigned to a (3,4)-connected topology (4.82)(4.6.83.10)(4.6.8)(4.6.82.10.12).

elements.content: As summarized in Table , the structural parameters illustrate the relationship between the pillars and the layers in more details. Within the layer, there is only one ω value in 1−5, indicating that the Zn2(atz)2 moieties link each other in a similar way, while in 6−8 the ω has four or two values, showing that the linkages are more complex and the layers are more corrugated (Figure S21 of the ).

Within the layer, there is only one ω value in 1-5, indicating that the Zn2(atz)2 moieties link each other in a similar way, while in 6-8 the ω has four or two values, showing that the linkages are more complex and the layers are more corrugated (Figure S21 of the ).

elements.content: As described above, the shape of the Zn(atz) layers can be described by the parameters ϕ and d 1 (Figure S22 of the ). While the length of the pillar increases, the change of ϕ exhibits a U-shaped trend, and the values for 4 and 5 are at the bottom. The d 1 increases slowly from 1 to 5 but abruptly rises to 6.72 Å for 6, being the maximum d 1 in all of the structures, and then slightly decreases in 7 and 8. This shows that the Zn(atz) layer is flexible enough to twist from being virtually planar to markedly corrugated.

While the length of the pillar increases, the change of ϕ exhibits a U-shaped trend, and the values for 4 and 5 are at the bottom. The d 1 increases slowly from 1 to 5 but abruptly rises to 6.72 Å for 6, being the maximum d 1 in all of the structures, and then slightly decreases in 7 and 8. This shows that the Zn(atz) layer is flexible enough to twist from being virtually planar to markedly corrugated.

elements.content: The parameters φ and d 2 can be used to describe the connection between layers and pillars (Figure S23 of the ). φ decreases from 90° in 2 to 30.5° in 8, indicating that the pillar is more and more slanted against the layer. The φ values form three obvious groups, that is, 2 and 3, 4 and 5, and 6−8, associated with the 3D topologies, or the pillaring fashions of these pillared-layered structures. d 2 increases rapidly from 6.25 Å in 1 to 12.72 Å in 5, because the pillars in 2 to 5 have certain rigidity and are difficult to be distorted. After 5, d 2 no longer increases but slowly decreases from 5 to 8, which is the result of topology change or the decrease of slanting angle φ.

elements.content: Obviously, this Zn(atz) layer undergoes diverse, drastic deformations in the construction of this series of 3D pillared-layer MOFs (Figure ). All of these observations connect to the fact that both the layers and the pillars are flexible and tend to form close-packed structures to prevent from the formation of “vacuum”, in which the flexibility of the dicarboxylate pillars may play a critical role in inducing the structural change. This fact implies that long and flexible dicarboxylates are not very appropriate pillars for the construction of porous pillared-layer MOFs, although they may be expected to generate flexible and even dynamic porous pillared-layer MOFs.

elements.content: Compound 1 is stable up to 250 °C before the framework gradually collapses between 250 and 500 °C. Compound 2 loses water molecules gradually and decomposes above 300 °C. For 3, the first weight loss takes place between 30 and 150 °C, which can be assigned to the removal of water molecules (observed, 6.6 wt %; calculated, 6.7 wt %). Compound 4 displays a high thermal stability, as there is no significant weight loss up to 340 °C. Compound 5 loses water molecules from 30 to 110 °C (observed, 3.3 wt %; calculated, 3.9 wt %) and then gives a well-defined plateau till 210 °C. The TGA curves of 6, 7, and 8 are very similar, and they are all stable up to 320 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Properties

Compound 1 is stable up to 250 °C before the framework gradually collapses between 250 and 500 °C. Compound 2 loses water molecules gradually and decomposes above 300 °C. For 3, the first weight loss takes place between 30 and 150 °C, which can be assigned to the removal of water molecules (observed, 6.6 wt %; calculated, 6.7 wt %). Compound 4 displays a high thermal stability, as there is no significant weight loss up to 340 °C. Compound 5 loses water molecules from 30 to 110 °C (observed, 3.3 wt %; calculated, 3.9 wt %) and then gives a well-defined plateau till 210 °C. The TGA curves of 6, 7, and 8 are very similar, and they are all stable up to 320 °C.

elements.content: To examine the sorption properties of 2 and 3, N2 sorption measurements have been performed at 77 K. The samples were desolvated at 100 °C for 10 h under vacuum to prevent framework collapse. Compound 2 possesses a reversible type I isotherm (Figure S18 of the ), characteristic of microporous material with the BET surface area about 104 m2/g. The Horvath−Kawazoe (HK) model indicates a pore diameter of 2 ca. 4.8 Å (Figure S19 of the ), which is consistent with the X-ray analysis. Although the crystal structure of 3 contains solvent accessible volume, it exhibited no significant sorption (Figure S20 of the ), which is consistent with its small pore windows (2.12 × 2.31 Å2).

The Horvath-Kawazoe (HK) model indicates a pore diameter of 2 ca. 4.8 Å (Figure S19 of the ), which is consistent with the X-ray analysis. Although the crystal structure of 3 contains solvent accessible volume, it exhibited no significant sorption (Figure S20 of the ), which is consistent with its small pore windows (2.12 × 2.31 Å2).

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully synthesized a series of new coordination polymers of Zn(II), 3-amino-1H-1,2,4-triazolates with different carboxylates, in which the 2D Zn(atz) layers can be pillared by different bridging dicarboxylates (carbonate, oxalate, and aliphatic dicarboxylates) into 3D structures. Interestingly, the Zn(atz) layer is able to adapt to the increasing flexible dicarboxylate through structural deformation, showing that the Zn(atz) layer is also flexible, comparable to other types of flexible layer. Porous pillared-layer structures have been constructed by unprecedented, very short carbonate and oxalate pillars, which demonstrate permanent porosity. On the other hand, long and flexible pillars do not favor porous structures. Nevertheless, considering the flexible nature of the building blocks, dynamic porosity of these seemingly nonporous pillared-layer MOFs cannot be ruled out, especially for higher temperature and pressure.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully synthesized a series of new coordination polymers of Zn(II), 3-amino-1H-1,2,4-triazolates with different carboxylates, in which the 2D Zn(atz) layers can be pillared by different bridging dicarboxylates (carbonate, oxalate, and aliphatic dicarboxylates) into 3D structures. Interestingly, the Zn(atz) layer is able to adapt to the increasing flexible dicarboxylate through structural deformation, showing that the Zn(atz) layer is also flexible, comparable to other types of flexible layer. Porous pillared-layer structures have been constructed by unprecedented, very short carbonate and oxalate pillars, which demonstrate permanent porosity. On the other hand, long and flexible pillars do not favor porous structures. Nevertheless, considering the flexible nature of the building blocks, dynamic porosity of these seemingly nonporous pillared-layer MOFs cannot be ruled out, especially for higher temperature and pressure.

cln_elements.content:
Compound 1 is stable up to 250 °C before the framework gradually collapses between 250 and 500 °C. Compound 2 loses water molecules gradually and decomposes above 300 °C. For 3, the first weight loss takes place between 30 and 150 °C, which can be assigned to the removal of water molecules (observed, 6.6 wt %; calculated, 6.7 wt %). Compound 4 displays a high thermal stability, as there is no significant weight loss up to 340 °C. Compound 5 loses water molecules from 30 to 110 °C (observed, 3.3 wt %; calculated, 3.9 wt %) and then gives a well-defined plateau till 210 °C. The TGA curves of 6, 7, and 8 are very similar, and they are all stable up to 320 °C.

To examine the sorption properties of 2 and 3, N2 sorption measurements have been performed at 77 K. The samples were desolvated at 100 °C for 10 h under vacuum to prevent framework collapse. Compound 2 possesses a reversible type I isotherm (Figure S18 of the ), characteristic of microporous material with the BET surface area about 104 m2/g. The Horvath−Kawazoe (HK) model indicates a pore diameter of 2 ca. 4.8 Å (Figure S19 of the ), which is consistent with the X-ray analysis. Although the crystal structure of 3 contains solvent accessible volume, it exhibited no significant sorption (Figure S20 of the ), which is consistent with its small pore windows (2.12 × 2.31 Å2).
